Posts.Title: I may have to ride this train!

Posts.Content: If Chemo is not going to cure him, then why do it? Chemo is often give in late stage cancer as a palliative measure...for instance a tumour could by pressing on a nerve or vital organ cause serious pain and chemo is given to shrink the tumour and relieve the symptoms. This is the usual reason chemo is given the other is that the relatives or the patient push the doctor in doing Chemo against the doctor's judgement in the vain hope of a cure...mind you any cancer can spontaneously go into remission but that is rare event. These are the 2 main reasons doctors do chemo in terminal cancers. Two other things to remember...doctor are human. This means they make mistakes and like the rest of the population of doctors contains a few bad apples. The last thing to remember is in Question and Answer format Q.... What do you call a medical student who came last in his class ? A.... Doctor ! Caveat Emptor

Posts.Title: New to the board

Posts.Content: Zak you are not going to be able to dodge a biopsy period. Any minimally invasive screen you take will always require a biopsy prior to treatment. It is so for all cancers as tissue pathology is essential . As sure as the Sun rises Zak a tissue biopsy must be taken. You might as well get used to the idea and toughen up a bit otherwise forget everything and live your life as if nothing is wrong. Fighting cancer demands courage to make decisions which are inherently risky and prone to failure but the reward of life extended is worth it in my opinion. Zak you are new here. The PSA testing stuff is old hat and has been done to death. People have strong opinions and have posted them, so read the threads then give it a rest. The thing that you need to do is take into account the feelings of the other members here so pay attention to what Chuck said in his post. Put yourself in other peoples shoes before you start typing, that way you will avoid alienating the crew.

Posts.Title: First time with Bimix.(warning mildly graphic,un politically correct, funny,long)

Posts.Content: I wondered how my brothers in the US felt they were treated. This is an international forum. I am from Australia. Is it the word Cancer that causes a problem? No it's the disease that carries the stigma not the word. You can change the word to anything you want and the stigma from the disease will follow. People really don't know what to say. Your wife is right. To talk to someone with cancer about their disease is really too much for most to bear. Your story is a common one that has been told here many times. The other thing is that a lot of people really don't care after all why should they care about someone they hardly know? This is probably the reason no one responded to your poster. It hurts more when friends or family don't bother to call but as we say around here cancer always finds out who your real friends are, one of the silver linings to the dark cloud that is cancer. Anyway welcome to our international forum and good luck

Posts.Title: Study -Cialis doesnt help to maintain erectile function among radiotherapy patients

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 jdsky: There is no link -- possibly deleted by webmaster? I agree with your position. PSA tests saved my life, not once, but twice, following a recurrence. The President's Death Panel has gone on record as saying that only one life is saved for every one thousand PSA tests administered. My position is that 1,000 lives can then be saved with each one million PSA tests. And that's a good thing, even considering any side effects that may result from treatment. If the intent is to keep the population uninformed via a diagnostic test that has led to a 44% decline in PC deaths since 1992, then let's do away altogether with diagnostic testing. X-ray machines ? Trash them. CT scans? Same thing. MRIs? A horribly expensive test that could save millions of dollars for insurance companies and the federal government (Medicare, Medicaid, etc.) if we just destroy all of those machines. Then, like ostriches, we can all sink our heads in the sand permanently. Jim Jim quite frankly I have had a gutful of loopy US politics and I don't even live in the states. I don't want to read it here. Treat this place like a dinnertable...no talk of religion or politics please.

Posts.Content: The Zak beware the Dunning Kruger effect. Don't try to hard with the scientific papers as all it will do is confuse you more. Without years of training none of that stuff will make any sense. Papers are sometimes given with a plain English summary and those are worth your while if you come across them but seriously all the ones written in technical language intended for medical researchers should be avoided.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi ChemoMan! Not sure if the link posted by jdsky was removed or not. If in fact, you have 'edited out' the link, doesn't that contradict your logic about reading unappetizing information? One is not forced to read a link. If they so choose they can click on it and read the information far away from the dinner table. I say this based on the assumption that the info contained was educational and did not violate Forum Policy. The issue of limiting PSA testing appears to be peculiar to the U.S. and I believe that the majority of The Forum Brothers are from the U.S. I would hate to think that there will be "victims" of this policy who may suffer needlessly. Again not sure if you looked at it and not sure what info it contained. Hope it did not force you to grab and swallow a handful of antacids! Hope your summer is going well Down Under! MF Hi MF I do not moderate this forum as Chuck does a great job so I did not remove any links. I doubt that Chuck removed it as Jdsky has linking priveleges. The OP probably forgot to put it in....it happens sometimes. Jdsky if you read this how about including the link Please just keep the politics out. I have nothing against people having issues with the recent recommendation but please for the sanity of us not living in the US keep the loony politics out...and I am including both sides of politics here. There are plenty of websites were you can express your political leanings. Despite what our media here think we really don't care about your politics in fact we are fed up already and your election is months away. Anyway I am back to lurking...happy posting people !

Posts.Content: But, we may expect this study to heat up the discussion on allowing posts for those medicines. No not going to happen As the study point out Alt does not work for cancer and people do worse when on it...with the exception of Pca. Now you chaps are not going to like what I write next but I think it needs to be said For years now your peak medical bodies have been telling the medical profession that they are over treating Pca especially in older men. This seems to indicate there may be some truth to this. Also the study did not say alts improve outcomes in Pca just that it makes no difference. For every other cancer the outcomes are worse. PO18guy's analysis of the study is also accurate and his comments are valid. So no the policy will not change. However you are as long standing members here allowed to discuss this issue...just don't start advocating stuff that does not work and in general makes people worse. Complimentary therapies are allowed to be discussed as always but alternatives to proven science based medicine are not. That ,to me, is like advocating for murder. If we relaxed the policy this place will become a cesspool of cranks, charlatans and snake oil salesmen...the internet is littered with cancer forums where this has happened. Science works.

Posts.Title: Old stickies???

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by cy7 History from August 2010, aged 54 years. After Blood Tests, MRI, Transrectal biopsy, cystoscopy, bone scan etc. Diagnosis: PSA: 050810: 8.1 Gleason Score 9 (4+5), with cancer in 15 of the 18 tissue cores, ductal adenocarcinoma present, peri neural invasion present, extra prostatic extention identified. Prostate volume was 71cc. Stage 3a/b Prostate Cancer (second opinion) Seminal vesicles, lymph nodes and bone scan clear. I was advised that surgery would not be a good idea, as there would be positive margins, and the risk of incontinence, and impotence almost 100%. I said I would prefer Quality of life over quantity. Started hormone (Cyproterone ... 100 to 300 mg daily) therapy August to November 2010 After 3 months Hormone Therapy, into hospital for 3 days HDR Brachytherapy (Nov 2010), then 25 treatments of External Beam Radiation (Dec 2010/January 2011) …. 66.25 Gy (or 83 Gy, some confusion) of Radiation, (20.25 Gy HDR brachytherapy and 46 Gy EBR) Subsequent PSA readings: 060411: 0.49 (Oncologist said I was in remission) 250811: 0.63 061011: 0.75 (6 month *1.5) 040412: 1.6 (6 month *2.1 ….. 12 month * 3.25) 191012: 2.7 (6 month * 1.68 ….. 12 month * 3.60) ….. Urologist said it appear the cancer has metastasized. 090413: 6.5 (6 month *2.4 ….. 12 month *4) …… both urologist and Oncologist said it is indicative of Metastatic prostate cancer) Due for another PSA in October 2013, and as of April 2013, Bone Scans and MRI are clear. I have resisted hormone therapy, expect for the original 3 months, which was to reduce size of prostate to avoid damage to surround organs. I sort help from alternate therapies in conjunction with the medical approach, taking Selenium, zinc, Pawpaw leaf extract, Cranberry, Chromium, Bio-Curcumin, Lipoec etc. Recently in desperation, after 4 successive 6 monthly rises in PSA, and doubling time currently just over 4 months, I have started taking Baking Soda/Maple Syrup mix. I am no great believer in alternate therapy, but the medical approach from here on does not excite me much either. I am currently in good health. Some bladder irritation, but Bladder and Bowel not a problem, and sexual function fine. Sometime use Cialis or Alprostadil injections. Live on a farm and still work well, ride horses etc. A long an overly detailed post I know, but no point in telling half the story. Don't know if it is helpful to anyone, but I am open to any suggestions. Feel free to shift this post to the appropriate thread. I am getting a little lost on the site. Regards, Jim Hi Jim Moving this to the prostate cancer forum for you Good luck

Posts.Title: Peach pits

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by joeven Hi I have a very low PSA of 0.04 I am a g9 stage t4 prostate cancer victim, had all the chemo etc, on three monthly injections my PSA was 893, was diagnosed in June last year. My question I still suffer with stomach aches and pains and back ache ( although had the back X rayed and told no cancer there ) does anyone know if cancer can still spread even with a low PSA. Thanks guys. Joe Hi You have what we in the lymphoma forum call "the noise". This is the little voice in your head that says "cancer" every time you feel something out of the ordinary. It gets loudest at around two years after treatment. Chances are you are suffering longterm side effects from the chemo. That stuff is really toxic and quite capable of producing those symptoms. As always if you are really concerned you should talk it over with your doctor. Chances are that something else could be at play and a doctor can investigate that for you. Congratulations on achieving NED...long may it last

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by goodlife307 My newly diagnosed G9 husband (age 59) has decided to go the new early chemo route before surgery. He just had his second infusion the other day. Back in January, before the DX, we noticed that he had a large hard lump under his skin on the top of his thigh. It was about 6 inches below his hip bone. With all of the the trauma of the diagnosis we kind of forgot about it. Then after his first round of chemo we have noticed that it has almost completely disappeared. While some might say this is good, I am worried that this might be a metastasis. His MRI did show two nodes as suspicious in the pelvic region but his bone scan was clean. We asked the oncologist about it the other day and he said without doing a biopsy it's hard to know what it is and that it would not change our current course of treatment. He wants hubby to do CT scans after the next round of chemo. My question to all of you is have you ever heard of anything like this relating to PC? Or could it be another type of cancer? If it is prostate cancer, I would think that this would take surgery off the table, meaning that it is now systematic. (Just entered my signature today; hope it shows up) Any insights would be much appreciated!!! Lymphoma acts like that. Could be that hubby has lymphoma as well. Best to talk to his doctors rather than us

Posts.Title: A Little Humor - Kids Say the Darndest Things

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by corvus917 So, after having to readmit my 80 year old father into the hospital twice in a month due to dehydration, weakness in the legs and back pain, we had him take a PSA test and a CT scan and an ultrasound. The results of the test was a PSA of 300, and the scans indicated that the prostate had a volume of 81 CCs, and there were calcifications and growths on the spine, which would suggest metastasis. Our doctor told our father the results of the tests, but we chose not to tell him that we thought it was cancer. My mother and I just told him that he needed a biopsy. Thing is that he refused to have a biopsy, since he hates hospitals (calls them places where "people go to die") and said that he "didn't want them to find anything else wrong with me", and he just wanted to leave. Now he's home two days later, and we're taking care of him, but we don't know how to tell him what is wrong with him. We thought he figured it out himself, but it seems that he's oblivious to what's wrong with him. He's too frail for chemo or radiotherapy, it's a struggle to get him to eat or drink anything even with appetite stimulants, and he can't even stand on his own. We haven't seen an oncologist yet, and we don't know how long he has left. I don't know what to do. I think that maybe your Father knows more than you think he does. I would leave the cancer diagnosis and reporting it to Dad to the oncologist. At the end of the day your Fathers wishes need to be respected and given the information you have provided I doubt whether Dad having full knowledge of his health status makes any difference. No need to burst his bubble if that is what keeps him sane. Don't fret over this. every second now is precious so make the most of it . Enjoy Dads company and go out of your way to make him laugh and feel at ease. Good luck

We thought he figured it out himself, but it seems that he's oblivious to what's wrong with him. He's too frail for chemo or radiotherapy, it's a struggle to get him to eat or drink anything even with appetite stimulants, and he can't even stand on his own. We haven't seen an oncologist yet, and we don't know how long he has left. I don't know what to do. I think that maybe your Father knows more than you think he does. I would leave the cancer diagnosis and reporting it to Dad to the oncologist. At the end of the day your Fathers wishes need to be respected and given the information you have provided I doubt whether Dad having full knowledge of his health status makes any difference. No need to burst his bubble if that is what keeps him sane. Don't fret over this. every second now is precious so make the most of it . Enjoy Dads company and go out of your way to make him laugh and feel at ease. Good luck

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MarkVA For most of my life, I've always been active and worked out. I learned (hard way lol) that its not good idea during treatment ... especially anything that is core related (hint - you'll be peeing every 3 1/2 minutes ... no kidding ... from the additional irritation to the area). But now that we've put some time and distance ... what are your experiences, advice, and medical feedback. I've been told to "give myself a break and take it easy". I get that. But it's hard for me as I am sure many. I really don't enjoy working out - I just like the results and free endorphin high (lol). BUT - if I'm going to do it .. then I'm going to do it, and push myself. I don't know if its the radiation or Lupron side effects ... but I'm achy in varying places (achy .. not pain). I was in great shape before - so I know its not respite during treatment. I find more I work out (or harder) .... less I seem to ache post workouts. I had to lay off for week due to travel ... and I seemed to ache more. What I don't want to do and am afraid of ... is work out too intensely or often. Listening to doc and nurse (take it easy, etc) I simply do 30 minutes of circuit/station training: weights, row machine and treadmill (I hate running - especially since Army .. so I just fast walk at incline) ... aside from rowing I stay away from core-isolating exercises (kettle bells, etc). My THR maintains about 130 +/- ... I'm not running marathons or a sprinter ... so that's fine with me. What do you all do? Thoughts? Am I overdoing it - or ok? Thanks!!!!! Well as long as you listen to your body you can knock yourself out. Repeated studies have shown that A hard workout on a regular basis together with adequate sleep and a healthy diet is the best recipe for a prolonged remission. Good luck

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago Well, I hope I can see the actual study instead of only the abstract. The abstract said " When adjusted for age and prostate weight, ASI men still had a greater probability of having GS 7 or greater PCa " But the world prostate cancer statistics you refer to only include diagnosed cases and/or death rates from PCa, potentially leaving out a large number of the men in this study who, but for death from other causes, might never be diagnosed or have died from prostate cancer. I don't know the details, but screening for PCa in Japan is far lower. Thus naturally you'll have much lower incidence of PCa being reported. It may be that Russian and Japanese rates of screening are roughly comparable. Rates of new diagnosed cases per 100,000 (back in 2002) were similar in both Russia and Japan. http://www.gapminder.org/world/#$majorMode=chart$is;shi=t;ly=2003;lb=f;il=t;fs=11 ;al=30;stl=t;st=t;nsl=t;se=t$wst;tts=C$ts;sp=6;ti= 2002$zpv;v=0$inc_x;mmid=XCOORDS;iid=phAwcNAVuyj1ji MAkmq1iMg;by=ind$inc_y;mmid=YCOORDS;iid=phAwcNAVuy j3qX39HWaQjEg;by=ind$inc_s;uniValue=8.21;iid=phAwc NAVuyj2vXUZJKI0XHA;by=ind$inc_c;uniValue=255;gid=C ATID0;by=grp$map_x;scale=log;dataMin=377;dataMax=7 5860$map_y;scale=lin;dataMin=-2.3805;dataMax=135$map_s;sma=49;smi=2.65$cd;bd=0$i nds=i110_t002002,,,,;i184_t002002,,,, And in this chart, you can also compare. http://cebp.aacrjournals.org/content...3/F3.large.jpg Interesting. Lots of factors involved. I'd like to see the entire study with the details. It may be that genetics or especially the lifestyle of Japanese men forestalls their PCa from advancing to the point of obvious symptoms (diagnosis) or death. Gleason 6's and 7's may not advance so rapidly in those who have lived and eaten differently for their entire life. Of question is whether Western men, changing their diets after age 50, or after diagnosis will make a significant change in progression. I've completely altered my diet for over 7 years now but have no great faith it will do much more than perhaps delay my genetics. Thus far, no positive biopsy, but PSA still poking along at 3.5 to 3.8 (with some worrying leaps up here and there). That is why I watch and wonder about these types of reports. How come Japanese men can have considerable rates of PCa ongoing, yet have a mortality rate half of ours. Obesity rates are lower in Japan and they eat more fish would seem the obvious reasons to me I heard a leading Australian oncologist talking about risk factors recently and the reporter brought up the issue of fermented and red meats and the oncologist basically brushed it off saying that the biggest risk factor for most men is obesity. Also heard that by the age of 80, roughly 80% of men have prostate cancer but most are indolent
